note: Seeded from Okonkwo Y4 teacher simulation feedback. Extended editorially to Y3, Y5, Y6 following the same reading-to-writing pattern: analysing language in reading feeds into vocabulary/structure choices in composition.

links.rationale: Okonkwo: 'Analysing effective language in texts (reading) directly feeds into vocabulary choices when editing own writing.' Children who notice powerful word choices in reading apply them in revision.
Okonkwo: 'Understanding how authors structure texts for meaning directly applies to composing structured paragraphs.' Language/structure analysis (reading) informs paragraphing (writing).
Okonkwo: 'Analysing narrative structure — plots, settings, character arcs — informs creating effective narratives.' Structure/presentation (reading) feeds into narrative elements (writing).

Okonkwo: 'Non-fiction organisational features (headings, subheadings, bullet points) are learned through reading and applied in writing.' Structure analysis (reading) feeds into organisational devices (writing).

Okonkwo: 'Performing poetry and plays directly connects to rehearsing sentences orally before writing.' Poetry/play performance (reading) and oral rehearsal (writing) share the same performative skill.
Okonkwo: 'Traditional story structures — hero journey, resolution — are the model for narrative composition.' Fairy stories/myths (reading) provide the structural templates for narrative writing.

Okonkwo: 'Children who can discuss books critically can evaluate writing critically.' Justifying views about texts (reading) and evaluating own writing (writing) are the same critical thinking skill applied in different directions.
Effective language in texts (reading) feeds into editing for grammar, vocabulary and consistency (writing). Y3 equivalent of Okonkwo's Y4 reading-to-editing pattern.
Language, structure and presentation (reading) informs paragraphing in composition (writing). Y3 equivalent of Okonkwo's Y4 structure-to-paragraphing pattern.
Structure/presentation analysis (reading) feeds into narrative elements — setting, character, plot (writing). Y3 equivalent of Okonkwo's Y4 structure-to-narrative pattern.
Poetry and play performance (reading) connects to oral rehearsal of sentences (writing). Y3 equivalent of Okonkwo's Y4 performance-to-rehearsal pattern.
Fairy stories, myths and legends (reading) provide structural templates for narrative elements (writing). Y3 equivalent of Okonkwo's Y4 fairy-stories-to-narrative pattern.

Authorial language analysis (reading) informs audience, purpose and form choices in writing. Understanding why authors choose particular language helps children make deliberate choices in their own writing.
Cross-text comparison (reading) develops awareness of how different texts serve different purposes, directly supporting audience/purpose/form awareness in writing.
Advanced inference and evidence-based reasoning about character/setting (reading) feeds into narrative writing with detailed characterisation, setting, and atmosphere (writing).

Critical evaluation of authorial language and structure (reading) parallels writing with conscious grammatical control (writing). Both require metalinguistic awareness — the ability to think about language as a tool.

Understanding plot and narrative structure (reading) directly informs narrative writing with authorial control (writing). Analysing how published authors construct narratives supports children's own narrative craft.
Comparing and contrasting texts (reading) develops awareness of genre conventions, directly supporting writing for different purposes with appropriate form.

Critical evaluation of authorial language (reading) feeds into drafting, editing and improving writing. Children who can critique published authors' choices can apply the same critical lens to their own drafts.
